doc.title: New US tariffs mean more uncertainty, Mining/Cables/Marine outperform

passages.text: Capital Goods Scandi Trip

We met 13 Scandi industrials last week: 1) tariff headwinds strengthening, 2) Mining equipment offers best growth prospects, 3) Large project hesitance persists, 4) Pricing (to offset tariffs) to lift growth rates from 2H, 5) European industrial activity staying soft. Key OWs: SAND, ALFA, LR, NKT.

1. Recent increase in US tariffs (India, Brazil, Section 232) could impact margins / demand, at least temporarily.  
2. Further evidence of mining equipment upcycle: large copper greenfields moving towards FIDs, easier access to financing for smaller gold producers.  
3. Hesitation around investment decisions in the US appear to continue for now, uncertainty has not yet subsided.  
4. Tariff-related price increases could lift organic growth rates in 2H25 and into 2026. Several companies suggested they would like to maintain margins after those price increase (not just offset costs).  
5. Little signs of a European industrial recovery; 'I believe it when I see it' approach to German stimulus.

Stocks in focus on the trip: NKT (OW) - strong execution continues and improved order intake outlook for 2H. SKF (EWL)- November CMD with strategic targets for industrial business could re- base the investment case. SAND (OW)/EPIA (OW)/METSO (UW) - clearly accelerating growth for Mining equipment. We see SAND as best placed. ATCOA (EW) - return to historical growth rates might take time. KONE (UW) - company remains confident on execution, while we see further downside potential to consensus (incremental tariffs + China headwinds), uncertainty about Modernisation order growth and risks to premium valuation.

More Positive demand expectations: Mining was a stand out in terms of the near- and medium- term outlook: continuing robust activity in gold (favourable project economics + widened access to financing), complemented with firming outlook for Copper greenfields (first
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 7. Completed: 31-Aug-25, 23:16 GMT Released: 01- Sep- 25, 04:00 GMT Restricted - External
European Capital Goods NEUTRAL Unchanged

contracts possible in early 2026). Marine continues to see solid demand supported by 10y-high shipyard backlogs, hence OEM revenue should continue to grow (despite current airpocket in contracting). HV cables continue to face a very strong cyclical backdrop (translating into better pricing and T&Cs), while NKT was also constructive on the near-term order intake in 2H25. US non- Resi demand appears to be improving, consistent with ASSA's commentary.

More cautious outlook: The feedback from our Scandi trip suggests softness in: US trucks (more production idling during 3Q, limited room for demand improvement before year end), appliances (continuing softness across key regions), infrastructure (underlying improvement limited, stock levels not as low across some products), pulp & paper, China construction (continuing decline in volumes and further pricing pressure), energy storage ('standstill' in the US drives tougher competition everywhere else), autos (tariffs and demand).

Our key stock calls in CapGoods: Overweights: SAND (cheapest larger- cap in the sector, best paced for Mining equipment growth), ALFA (misunderstood marine cycle), LR (organic growth upside, DC mix shift), SCHP (self- help, room for guidance upgrade), PRY/NKT (high- voltage driven growth & margins). Underweights: SIE (the most expensive euro electrical, risks to growth & CMD expectations), ALO (cash flow headwinds reviving B/S concerns), VWS (largely non- cash profits in Service business, unwinding of US regulatory support to renewables, downside risk to consensus orders/growth/margins/FCF), KONE (high- 20s FY25E P/E despite incremental headwinds in China, risks to longevity of modernisation cycle, FX/tariff risks), ABB (peaking demand with limited valuation support, in our view), NIBE (competition and pricing risk with material earnings downside risk), LIGHT (tariff headwinds), and ELUX (structural headwinds from competition on top of Latin America likely peaking).
Assa Abloy (EW): positive signs in parts of the US market

- Management continue to see incremental demand recovery, led principally by non-resi in the U.S. that spans the Americas, Global Tech and Entrance Systems divisions. In the latter, management see a 2H step up in growth thanks to delivery of orders taken in the industrial (warehouse) segment earlier in the year.- Residential recovery will be much more gradual however. Pockets of "green shoots" have been seen in areas such as Sweden, supported by interest rate cuts, and encouragingly management signal U.S. residential has stabilised, though questions remain on the volume outlook near-term as tariffs increase overall building / renovation costs.- Tariff related pricing is expected to be 3-4% across Assa's US exposure. Interestingly, management expect price increases to maintain gross margins and not merely match the dollar cost increase. That said, underlying price vs cost tailwinds that have supported margins in the past several quarters are set to reduce.- M&A pipeline remains buoyant with focus areas including adjacencies and scaling or consolidating focus regions e.g. the U.S. and India. Interestingly, management continue to expect China to shrink in importance along with the deteriorating property market and appears to be de-emphasised from a capital allocation perspective. Though looking further ahead there is an expectation that Chinese competitors look to enter European markets more meaningfully.- Financial algorithm unlikely to change at the CMD; management continue to believe the 5-10% sales growth rate (excluding FX) and a 16-17% adj EBIT margin are the right targets for the business.

- Broader industrial demand and recovery will likely be gradual, but sees no reason why historical growth rates wouldn't be back.- Adding capacity in China continue to see region as a clear opportunity for key business lines incl. vacuum (semis) and compressors (replacement + efficiency).- Demand for smaller compressors is healthy, larger compressors continue to see hesitance from customers (and tougher order intake comp).- Profitability effects from footprint optimisation in Vacuum should start being visible in the coming quarters.- Industrial Technique faces low automotive capex, but long-term case remains in place.

- European demand remains soft, with no signs of recovery for now. Would like the see the market coming back to \(2 - 3\%\) growth rates.- US business is at an early stage of a turnaround, committed to \(6\%\) margin target with no timeline however.- Brazil is staying at a very solid level of last year, with margins impacted by less favourable mix.- The management considers balance sheet as stable, and plans to reduce leverage by improving profitability over time.- The company sees room to improve FCF in 2H25, partially due to working capital optimisation.

- Mining outlook is solid with increasing brownfield activity, several large greenfields in the pipeline and favourable replacement cycle for large surface drilling rigs.- Service growth was low in the past quarters, the company is working to bring it back to the trend (MSD growth).- Need to work with pricing to offset tariffs and FX, double digit price increases possible for selected product lines.- Infrastructure demand remains weak with limited signs of improvement, weaker volumes in the Attachments business continue to pressure profitability.- Adoption of electric machines have slowed down, but EPIA believes it will continue to gain share over time.
- Still sees cost cutting opportunities (incl. in IT) and room to increase attachment rates on spare parts.

- More positive on larger Copper projects (in Latam), but think they start coming in 2H 2026, with potential peak in 2027-28.- Strong Gold activity, but projects for FLS are smaller than in Copper.- Open to inorganic growth opportunities: sees product gap in Mobile crushing which could only be filled by M&A (we note that: SAND and METSO are key suppliers of mobile crushing equipment).- Last strategic cycle was more about 'putting the house in order', next one should be about profitable growth.

- Continuing challenging new installations market in China: lower volume and deflationary pricing. Cash collection and overdue receivables remain in focus in the region.- Sees good growth potential in Modernisation still. No pricing pressure in this market for now. We note that both lift OEM with largest share of modernisation business, Kone and TK, reported significant slowdown in orders in 2Q.- Service growth appears to be seen driven by pricing and to a degree M&A, while units under maintenance growth has slowed somewhat recently.- Situation with US tariffs continues to be seen as manageable, as only c10% of US COGS are imported. We note that recent expansion of Section 232 might bring additional tariff impacts.

- Positive demand outlook in Mining: several large copper greenfields moving in the right direction, financing is much more accessible for smaller gold miners (projects going ahead).- Clear path for new equipment growth in the coming years, particularly as greenfield portion rebounds from a low base.- Aggregates demand picture is more mixed: Europe recovered somewhat from a low base, US continue to face uncertainties, while China is normalising lower.- Margins headwinds that were particularly prominent in 2Q are mostly of a one-off nature. Minerals margins should normalise already in 3Q, while in Aggregates normalisation might take a little longer.- Strategically the company is looking to be profitably positioned in the key product lines (potentially de-emphasising some), and would welcome further consolidation in Mining Equipment.

- NKT sees solid demand to the end of the decade (although affordability for customers starts to be a discussion point in Europe); solid visibility on 2H25 orders.- Terms and conditions on new projects are favourable for suppliers, reflecting Supply/Demand tightness.

- Less concerned about supply additions from competitors than 12m ago, given some projects were scaled back.- All appear on track with regards to capacity expansion and new vessel construction, but execution is key to deliver on growth strategy.

- Demand appears to be stable y/y in 3Q; some early signs of increasing enquiries, but too early to judge and too late to impact 3Q business anyway.- Pushing ahead with the separation, sticking to the original timeline (mid-2026), but process is complex so limited room for error.- CMD in November should detail the strategy and targets for RemainCo (Industrial business), and provide some first colour for SpinCo (Automotive business).- Believes that RemainCo should be a more profitable, diversified, less cyclical business.- Continue to execute incremental costs savings, reducing headcount and moving support functions into best cost countries.

- US Truck market is soft, Volvo and competitors executed meaningful cuts in 3Q, do not expect any regulation-related pre-buy before next year.- Europe saw improved Truck order intake hence added production. Have flexibility to cut back again if needed.- "I believe it when I see it" approach to German stimulus from Volvo customers.- European construction equipment demand appears to be bottoming; US still seeing incremental de-stocking.- US Tariffs turned out to be less disruptive for Volvo than feared initially (according to the company), given the impact on competitors' supply chains as well.

- Service 8% mid-term growth target: derived bottom-up: 2x of market growth (2% customer production + 2% pricing).- Arauco revenue phasing: talked about S curve before but this project will be evenly distributed over years.- H2 OE orders: tissue pipeline continues to look healthy- Cost saving: EUR 80m benefit per annum: associated cost will be higher but not far from the EUR 80m, yet to hit P&L/cash flow.- Flow control: 26% P&P, 74% other; needs to grow market share to reach growth target at 6% vs anticipated 3% market growth.- Inventories: company intends to bring it down but this takes some time.

- Marine outlook: despite weak ship yard contracting data, Wartsila continues to see a positive market due to elevated activity levels in Cruise, potential replacement cycle in Ferries, and extended shipyard backlogs overall.- Thermal Energy outlook is seen as stable, specifically highlighting that order intake seen in 2Q25 doesn't happen very often. Sees continuing interest from Datacenter customers, but hard to frame the size of the market going forward (incl. relative to a very big order intake for the industry in 2Q).- Energy storage is a challenging market with 'stand still' environment in the US driving competition (incl. pricing pressure) in other regions.- Service: despite negative order growth in 2Q, WRT expects service sales to remain on a positive trajectory. We came back with the impression that strong growth rates seen over the past three years, might be harder to repeat going forward.- Extended backlog translates to elevated pre-payment position. Wartsila confirms that every equipment order requires a down payment, hence increasing duration of the backlog supported cash flows in the recent quarters. Engine slots largely sold out to the end of 2026.

We, Jonathan Hurn, CFA, Timothy Lee, CFA, Vlad Sergievskii, Xin Wang, George Featherstone, CFA and Amit Batra, hereby certify (1) that the views expressed in this research report accurately reflect our personal views about any or all of the subject securities or issuers referred to in this research report and (2) no part of our compensation was, is or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this research report.
Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the "industry coverage universe":
Aston Martin Lagonda plc (AML.) Daimler Truck (DTGGE.DE) FORVIA (FRVIA.PA) Michelin (MICP.PA) Renault SA (RENA.PA) Valeo (VLOP.PA)
BMW AG (BMWG.DE) Dowlais (DWL.L) Gestamp (GEST.MC) Porsche AG (P911_p.DE) Stellantis N.V. (STLAM.MI) Volkswagen AG Prefs (VOWG_p.DE)
Continental (CONG.DE) Ferrari N.V. (RACE.MI) Mercedes-Benz Group AG (MBGn.DE) Porsche Automobil Holding SE (PSHG_p.DE) TRATON (8TRA.DE) Volvo AB (VOLVb.ST)

ABB (ABBN.S) Andritz AG (ANDR.VI) AutoStore (AUTO.OL) FLSmidth & Co. (FLS.CO) Jungheinrich (JUNG_p.DE) Kone OYJ (KNEBV.HE) Nexans SA (NEXS.PA) Nordex SE (NDXG.DE) Rexel SA (RXL.PA) Schneider Electric (SCHN.PA) Signify (LIGHT.AS) Valmet OYJ (VALMT.HE) Wartsila (WRTTV.HE)

Alfa Laval AB (ALFA.ST) Assa Abloy (ASSAb.ST) Electrolux (ELUXb.ST) Fluidra (FLUI.MC) KION (KGX.DE) Legrand (LEGD.PA) NIBE (NIBEb.ST) Prysmian SpA (PRY.MI) Sandvik AB (SAND.ST) Siemens AG (SIEGn.DE) SKF AB (SKFb.ST) VAT Group (VACN.S)

Alstom (ALSO.PA) Atlas Copco AB (ATCOa.ST) Epiroc AB (EPIRa.ST) GEA Group (G1AG.DE) Knorr-Bremse (KBX.DE) Metso (METSO.HE) NKT A/S (NKT.CO) Rational (RAAG.DE) Schindler Holding (SCHP.S) Siemens Energy (ENR1n.DE) Trelleborg (TRELb.ST) Vestas (VWS.CO)

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
